results:
The search results provide extensive information about Aldous Huxley, his dystopian literature, and Polish academic research on his works. Here's a summary of the findings:

## Polish Academic Research on Aldous Huxley

The search revealed a significant Polish academic publication: "Nowe wspaniałe światy Aldousa Huxleya i ich recepcja w Polsce" (Aldous Huxley's Brave New Worlds and Their Reception in Poland) - described as "The first Polish presentation of the whole literary output of Aldous Huxley (1894-1963), outstanding British novelist and essayist, the author of Brave New World (1932) – a dystopia considered to be one of the most important books of 20th century."(no content)This Polish academic work "discusses Huxley's novels and non-fiction, taking into consideration the most recent publications of both Polish and English-speaking literary scholars" and "describes the history of Polish translations of Huxley's works as well as their reception in Poland, paying particular attention to two Polish translations of Brave New World."

## University Research

Additional Polish university research was found at the University of Wrocław, with a publication titled "Obrazy edukacji w dystopii 'Nowy wspaniały świat' Aldousa Huxleya" (Images of Education in the Dystopia "Brave New World" by Aldous Huxley).

## Huxley's Dystopian Literature

"Nowy wspaniały świat" (Brave New World) is described as "Fantastyczna, dystopijna opowieść rozgrywająca się w dalekiej przyszłości, kiedy to postęp nauki umożliwi ogromny rozwój inżynierii społecznej, jest do dziś uważana za proroctwo i przestrogę" (A fantastic, dystopian story set in the distant future, when scientific progress will enable enormous development of social engineering, is still considered a prophecy and warning today).(no content)The work was compared to George Orwell's "1984," and "the author himself later compared his own vision to that of Orwell in his letters."

## Huxley's Background in English Literature

Huxley "studied English literature at Oxford" after attending Eton College.(no content)He "studied at Oxford, at Balliol College, obtaining a bachelor's degree in English literature."

The search results show substantial Polish academic interest in Huxley's dystopian works, with comprehensive studies examining both his literary output and its reception in Poland, published by university presses and academic institutions.
